bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to John J. Moran, October 12, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] discusses the identity of the shack on the Rojas farm.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to John J. Moran, October 12, 1940
div1.opener:
In the long ronrun, I should think Mr. Z. would be proud to have his home and the
birthplace of his children permanently memorialized, and therefore would be willing to
deal fairly with us, perhaps selling us the shack for no more than the cost to replace
it with a more livable affair, but I don't mean by this that I propose to build him a
modern house in return for the shack.
October 12, 1940
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Pogolotti, as I believe you
may not be able to carry out my request before you leave on the sixteenth. I was
delighted with the photographs and your note, and on examining them more carefully,
while I still have some doubt, I am much more acceptable to the idea that the shack
may be the remains of Building No. 1. I note that already they have torn down the
smaller shack and connecting between the two. Are they planning to tear down the
Building No. 1 also? Will either you or Mr. Pogolotti (perhaps the latter would
be better as he knows real estate values) act as my agent in at least sounding out
the owner of the shack on the cost of the shack and a small parcel of land, or
just the cost of the shack itself. It occurred to me that if the owner will treat
me fairly, I would take an option on it and then come down in February and decide
the matter. If I can buy the shack without too much cost, I would like to present
it to the government or to some memorial association composed of American and Cuban
physicians and governmental people. I am certainly not interested in taking the
responsibility of buying now any large amount of property around the shack. I am
only interested in protecting the shack. It might be better to move the shack
and place it in the left-hand corner of the Rojas property, surrounded by a fence
and protected by some sort of a concrete roof. Perhaps the Rojas family would be
sufficiently interested to give to a memorial association just that amount of land
on the corner of their property (that is, on Calzada Real) for the purpose. Or, it
might be better to give it to the government, to be transferred bodily to the site
of the false camp, and to be an integral part of their memorial. The accessories
which have been put on the shack could be removed and the remainder restored. All
of this depends on further investigation of the shack to assure those of us most
concerned that it is truly remnants of Building No. 1.

I assume that Mr. Zumzunequi is the owner, and I do hope that he won't
consider me a rich American, to be fleeced because of my interest in a historical
object which he happens to own. As a piece of wood which will eventually be torn
down anyhow, the shack probably isn't worth more than $50.00. As a historical object
which the Cuban government might buy, you know as well as I do that they will never
buy it, but they might graciously accept it from a private memorial association, par-
ticularly if we suggest that they transfer it to their own choice of sites. Supposing
I take out an option with a small down payment and by next Spring, we decide it isn't
true Building No. 1. If the cost of the option isn't too much, I am willing to take
this chance. I assure you I have no ulterior motive, do not wish to make any profit
and indeed, if the cost is not too great, I plan to give it to the Cuban government,
and will try to collect from others enough money to fix it up properly. In dealing
with Mr. Z. remember that I am just a physician on a salary. It is a good salary but
nonetheless I have children, taxes, etc. and cannot afford to get in this very deeply.
I would so appreciate some sort of word at your earliest convenience. Should you wish
to cable or send airmail letters, I will answer promptly and would feel much better if
the deal could be closed promptly, at least as far as an option is concerned, within the
next week or two. May I congratulate you on your zeal and thank you most heartily for
this further evidence of your cooperation, and of course this means Mr. Pogolotti as
well as yourself.
